subject: Your daily e-mail from the BBC
body:
Thursday, 19 April, 2007, 18:00 GMT 14:00 -04:00:Canada/Eastern














Search BBC Sport 













FOOTBALL




Owen may delay Newcastle comeback
Newcastle striker Michael Owen admits he may delay his comeback from a 10-month injury lay-off.



 
Wenger will stay, says Hill-Wood
Arsenal chairman Peter Hill-Wood says Arsene Wenger will stay at the club despite David Dein's departure.



 
Solskjaer reveals retirement plan
Man Utd striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer says he is likely to retire at the end of next season.








GOLF




Rose can 'top Faldo major record'
Justin Rose's coach says he can use his Masters experience to beat Nick Faldo's six majors.



 
Zurich Classic leaderboard
Score updates from the PGA Tour event in New Orleans.



 
Struggling Casey blames lost bags
Paul Casey lies six off the lead after the first round of the Asian Open in Shanghai, blaming lost luggage for his display.








MOTORSPORT




Schumacher vows to answer critics
Ralf Schumacher aims to turn around his season when his Toyato car is "competitive again"



 
Hamilton 'could become best ever'
Lewis Hamilton could go on to become the greatest racing driver of all time, his McLaren boss Martin Whitmarsh says.



 
Raikkonen rues missed opportunity
Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen thinks he could have won all three Grands Prix this season.








FORMULA ONE

Hamilton 'could become best ever'

ATHLETICS




Gebrselassie targets London 2012
Distance legend Haile Gebrselassie plans to extend his career and compete in the London 2012 Olympics.



 
Holmes set to race in Manchester
Double Olympic gold medallist Dame Kelly Holmes will take part in the Great Manchester Run.



 
O'Sullivan 11th in Dublin event
Sonia O'Sullivan has to settle for 11th place in her final road race on Irish soil in Sunday's Great BUPA Ireland Run.








CYCLING




Cavendish claims Belgian success
British cyclist Mark Cavendish held off a world-class field to win the Scheldeprijs Vlaanderen in Belgium.



 
O'Grady takes Paris-Roubaix glory
Stuart O'Grady becomes the first-ever Australian winner of cycling's Paris-Roubaix classic.



 
Cooke's winning run finally ends
Dutch rider Adrie Visser wins the third round of the World Cup, Nicole Cooke edged out in the final sprint.
